content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Le probl√®me reprend l'id√©e de trace monoids. Les jeux de test semblent plut√¥t complet, un partie pour aider √† la compr√©hension et un ensemble pousser pour s'assurer de la validit√© du code. Cela peut √™tre r√©solu en moins de cinq minutes, m√™me s'il n'est pas dans les plus simple.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very good idea, this is original and feasible by anybody. It's a good exercise to learn strings
Hi, I think it would be better to have a puzzle about Levenshtein distance, isn't ?

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: very well

I don't know what to do with this one, I still believe that it's probably too hard for a clash, but the identical easy puzzle version got no traction at all:

https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/55983104bc4bdbf5047ac67d0ddac9285603d

So I updated the testcases here too, and now I guess we see if enough people are willing to approve this over the puzzle version.

Edit:
- Added shortest mode
- Added a couple testscases including a test to prevent solutions that only checked for set equality among islands: 
aabcabb abbcaba c -> should be false
- changed this line of the stub
loop t read test:string(256)
to
loop t read base:word(200) target:word(200) fixed:word(200)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

This is too hard for a clash of code, but great for a puzzle.
If I see this come out another day as a puzzle, I would approve.

I agree with Ghouls_only_drink_coffee, you should precise "by unlimited swappings"

And then you can sumbit !

Good luck ! :D

You should explicitly put in statement that the adjacent letters can be swapped multiple times. At first I was a bit confused with "santa" => "satan" which is possible with at least two swaps, but I thought only one swap is available.

Interesting and fun puzzle. +1
I have to admit it took me more than 15 minutes but, I couldn't help myself to get a clean solution.
Why not include Shortest challenge ?

Interesting idea. If this does not get approved as a clash, you may submit it again as an Easy puzzle.

Test/Validator 6
* "vhmtlstucop vmhtlstucop fkycopls" violates the third constraint.

Goal section
* Suggest to change "Then, for each of the following t lines, you are given a space separated" to "Each test is a" for less repetition and also clarification of what a test is.

* For clarity, suggest to change the last sentence to:
Print {{true}} if you can reach [[target]], or {{false}} if you cannot.

Thanks.

New things:

- Simplified statement
- Tests are now multitest (allows to simplify the puzzle while avoiding binary output).
- Validators are just a reordering of the tests (so you can't hardcode it, it guarantees that you will pass all validators if you pass all tests, and it's also easier for me lol...)
- Fixed my previous solution which didn't pass some edge cases.
- Removed shortest.

This is actually easier than the previous version but still too long for a clash imo. I'm not sure how to simplify it even more so any ideas are welcomed.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Please change "If you do" to "If you can" in both Goal section and Output section.

Suggest to format "False" as a constant {{False}}.

Suggest to revise the stub generator as "True" is not an option.

Thanks.
Ideally I wanted the transformation cost to be the minimum amount of swaps required to go from base to target, but then it gets quite tricky for a clash I think.
Fixed, thanks as usual !

Nice catch for test/validator 6! Added some sanity checks to the solution to verify that I didn't screw it somewhere else.

Besides that, I changed a bit the statement following your suggestions.

Thanks!

3rd constraint: I'm not sure that is needed nor useful
4th constraint: Should be `0 < t < 256` since `t` represents `len(test)` and `test` is undefined

On line 31 of your solution, checking if the target char is fixed adds no value IMO. `|| fixed.includes(c2)` can be removed and everything still works.

If you're interested, here's one of my "pseudo-clean" solution : 

def main
  gets.to_i.times {
    puts process(*gets.split)
  }
end

class String
  def any?(other)
    (self & other).size > 0
  end

  def all?(other)
    (self - other).size == 0
  end

  private

  def &(other)
    (self.chars & other.chars)*""
  end

  def -(other)
    (self.chars - other.chars)*""
  end
end

def process(base, target, fixed)
  result = base == target
  unless result || (base.size != target.size || !base.all?(target) || base.all?(fixed))
    target.chars.each_with_index { |c, i|
      next if c == base[i]
      j = base.index(c, i)
      break if base[i..j].any?(fixed)
      base[i], base[j] = base[j], base[i]
      break if result = base == target
    }
  end
  result
end

main

For the 3rd constraint, it's definitely not needed, but it's coherent with the topic in that "you will only fix stuff that is relevant to the current test", so I don't really want to remove it.

For the 4th, "test" is just the string given (with spaces). You are right that this is not clear, so I updated the input section. This constraint is just an indication of the complexity of the problem.

The remark you raise about line 31 is very clever, works indeed, but seems to be the result of a bunch of logic mixed together that is not easy to see. I won't change it because I find it easier to think about it how I wrote it, but that was a very nice suggestion (Note that the comment at line 37 is no longer true if I do what you say, but that shows that it wasn't totally needed either).

Your solution is great, I was messing around a bit with it, and this is what I got:

https://bpa.st/63UUS

Ultimately you are right, this is more an easy puzzle than I clash. I think I will change that once I find some time.

Great, now `test` is clear in the 4th constraint.

For the rest, I was simply pointing it out, it's fine the way it is.

Nice work with the Ruby solution with arrays. üëç

Constraints section
* Please change "len" to "length".

Thanks.
Oops, I must have missed that one from the copy pasting. Thanks!
